thread.title: Walter Chang quits his job and visits 60 countries around the world
thread.title_full: Walter Chang quits his job and visits 60 countries around the world | Daily Mail Online

author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: Walter Chang quits his job and visits 60 countries around the world
text:
55 shares 3
View
comments
Showcasing 60 countries in less than four minutes, this video tells the story of one man's travels around the world.
Back in 2011 Walter Chang quit his job in the U.S, and after saving for two-and-a-half years, decided to act out his very own bucket list.
The trip became reality in 2011 when he trekked outside of his home country for only the third time in his life.
And he's not looked back since.
Walter Chang visits 60 countries in three years to find HOME The iconic Burning Man Festival in the Nevada Black Rock Desert was seen at first hand by the traveller
Abu Simbel Rock Temple in Egypt is a popular tourist attraction and was one of the highlights he ticked off
The valley of dead trees in Deadvlei desert in Namib-Naukluft Park, Namibia
'I went to Nepal and trekked to Everest Base Camp,' the 28 year old said.
'I did several self-drive safaris in southern Africa and fulfilled a childhood dream of seeing cheetahs. In India I took in the wondrous sights and sounds of Varnasi.
 Would you stay at the Titanic hotel? Now you can check into... Chilling footage shows panic in cabin of Chinese airliner as... Escape from the hungry hippos: Hapless impala nearly becomes... Cabin crew 'attacked and hospitalised' by six Chinese... 55 shares 'One year became two. Two became three. The endless travel felt like a drug-induced state. Each strange new place was exhilarating - a rush of new experiences.
'To keep costs down I hitchhiked and took 30 hour train rides throughout countries like China and India. I slept in airports, camped, and Couchsurfed.
'I had bad moments as well. I caught food poisoning several times, was robbed of everything in Chile, and nearly died when my car flipped over in the deserts of Namibia.'
The mesmerising Wat Rong Khun, or the White Temple, in Chiang Rai Province, Thailand
The moving Western Wall in Jerusalem was just one of the historic sites Mr Chang visited
Mr Chang made many friends along the way, of which he went on to share in his experiences
There were many achievements to note during Mr Chang's two-and-a-half year trip around the world, pictured here with a friend in Tanzania
THE 60 COUNTRIES WALTER CHANG HAS TICKED OFF HIS LIST

Mr Chang has documented his travels on his Kickstarter page , where he aims to raise $12,000 to produce a book detailing the weird and wonderful memories from his travels.
'Travelling in this manner is really an educational experience and investment in yourself,' he added.
'You get to see how other people live and how they view life. You also get time to reflect on your own issues from an altogether different perspective.
The stunning sights of the hot air balloons above Cappadocia in Turkey
Many moments throughout Mr Chang's worldwide tour are captured in the video
Seeing pandas up close in China was a fantastic experience for the intrepid world traveller
'In the end you may just come out wiser, more confident, and laid back. Then there’s the interaction with people vastly different from you who time after time are willing and eager to accommodate complete strangers, yet expecting nothing in return.
'The whole experience is incredibly humbling and urges you to give back in the same way.
'I've been extremely lucky going on an adventure like this. Capturing images and telling stories through a visual medium has always been an obsession of mine.
'Though I took a slight detour, photographing the people and places I visited during these travels gave me a chance to express this passion.'
Visiting 60 countries around the world left the 28-year-old with memories to treasure forever
The US-born thrillseeker takes on a bungee jump in this terrifying vertical drop
The start of the journey: Mr Chang packs up his stuff to set out to see the world
